results.title: Frontier: stories from white Australia's forgotten war: part one: they must always consider us as enemies 1788-1830
results.brief_description: Designed for the international market, this is a compilation of the 3 complete episodes screened on television and contained in the collection, with the addition of some footage that wasn’t televised on ABC- the overall effect is somewhat sanitised and apologetic.

results.title: Urban clan
results.creator_credit: Michelle Mahrer, Aanya Whitehead, Paul Humfress, MusicArtsDance Films and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: The Page brothers - Stephen, Russell and David - are Aboriginal artists of mixed blood, part Maori, British and Aboriginal, whose talents were channelled into, (as choreographer, performer and composer respectively), the Sydney based Bangarra Dance company. In this informative documentary, made in 1997, before the untimely death of Russell, the brothers discuss their upbringing, experiences of racism, artistic desires, history and aspirations. Additionally, they visit the family home where they examine, with their parents, their ancestry, experiences of growing up in a white man’s world, and connection to the past. The brothers identify as nurturers to a culture under siege, and aim to keep the Dreamtime alive in a modern context, recognising the performances of Bangarra Dance Theatre as a modern day corroboree, storytelling in a contemporary form, that bridges urban Aboriginality with traditional beliefs, whilst promoting indigenous culture. Also features excerpts from the successful production of “Fish”, as well as rehearsals, and archival footage, stills and video, from the boys’ childhood. A fascinating portrait of one immensely talented family.

results.title: Blackout: best kept secret: a profile of Archie Roach singer/songwriter
results.creator_credit: Llew Cleaver, Richard Reisz and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: ‘Best kept secret: a profile of Archie Roach singer/songwriter is part of ABC’s ‘Blackout’ series and provides an intimate account of one of one of Australia’s most popular contemporary indigenous performers. The video examines how Archie’s stolen childhood has affected his life and his music.
results.title_for_label: Blackout: best kept secret: a profile of Archie Roach singer/songwriter

results.title: Dust [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Ivan Sen, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon, Autumn Films, New South Wales Film and Television Office and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation
results.brief_description: 2 cars arrive at a desolate cotton property. One car carries two feuding white teenagers Amy (Nathalie Roy) and Mick (Tristan Bancks)- the other 2 aboriginal youths Leroy (Clayton Munro) and Vance (Wayne Munro) and an elderly aboriginal woman called Ruby (Peta Binge). Under the fast moving clouds a storm is brewing, and when racism reaches a head and the dust storm finally erupts, the 5 find themselves confined in a car where they can no longer flee the tragedy of the past. Nominated for three AFI awards, Ivan Sen’s final film received a special commendation at the Clermonth Ferrand Short Film Festival.

results.title: Arnhem Land
results.creator_credit: Charles P. Mountford and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Records the 1948 joint Australian-American expedition to Arnhem Land. Shows field work of scientists collecting specimens of insects, birds, fish, mammals, flowers, vegetation, rock structures, aboriginal paintings and carvings, etc. Several scenes show aborigines in ceremonial rituals, including the dances of the great kangaroo, the water snake, and the wild honey dances. Photographed by Peter Bassett-Smith, with music by Alfred F. Hill.

results.title: Australian aborigines: police tracker
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Explains how Jackie the full blooded aboriginal police tracker from Katherine learnt this skill, which enables the aboriginal to hunt and the police to keep law and order and to save lives in Australia’s outback. Taken during the University of Sydney’s 1952 expedition to Arnhem Land and produced in collaboration with Professor A.P. Elkin, Professor of Anthropology, University of Sydney.

results.title: Learning Walmajarri (PC & MAC)
results.creator_credit: Catholic Education Office of Western Australia
results.brief_description: SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: PC; Multimedia capable Pentium running Windows 95.16 megabytes RAM, (32 megabytes RAM recommended). Monitor 640 x 480 resolution, 16 bit colour (thousands of colours), 8X CD drive or faster. External speakers or headphones. MAC; 68040 (30Mhz) or better (Power PC recommended) running Mac 0S 7.5 or later. Minimum of 8 megabytes FREE application RAM. DO NOT USE VIRTUAL MEMORY. Monitor 640 x 480 resolution, 16 bit colour (thousands of colours). 8X CD drive or faster. Optional external speakers or headphones. Jointly funded by the Catholic Education Office in the Kimberley region and two schools - Kururrungku Catholic Education Centre and John Pujajangka Plyrin Catholic School, ‘Learning Walmajarri’ is the result of digitising elements of the program taught by tribal elders in the Walmajarri-speaking areas around Broome. “The multimedia format of a CD is well suited to the oral tradition, which is the context in which the elders teach their language, using songs and stories to impart vocabulary and syntax”(‘The Australian’ Tuesday June 8 199 pg. 20). Designed to assist in improving literacy amongst Walmajarri speakers, this program uses jigsaws and traditional stories and songs as entertaining instruction, although people who have no previous experience with Walmajarri may be tempted to give it a try.

results.title: Too many Captain Cooks
results.brief_description: This film seeks to replace the stereotypes promoted by the non-Aboriginal history of white settlement in Australia which usually begins with the ‘discoveries’ of Captain Cook. Here history is re-told from the point-of-view of the colonised: ‘Aboriginals discovered Captain Cook’. In Northern Australia white people are referred to as ‘Captain Cooks’. The film’s form is sensitive to the telling of tribal history of Captain Cook as spoken by Paddy Wambarranga of the Rembarrnga tribe in Arnhem Land. This history is also represented by images of Aboriginal art. Rembarrnga and Kriol dialogue with English subtitles.

results.title: The Coolbaroo club
results.creator_credit: Roger Scholes, Penny Robins, Australian Film Commission, Coolbaroo Club Productions and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: A study of what life was like for many Aboriginal Australians in post World War 11 Western Australia. For 14 years, between 1946 and 1960, the Coolbaroo Club in Perth, Western Australia, was a meeting place and a community focus for the local Aboriginal community. The Coolbaroo Club was unique in that it was the only Aboriginal-run dance club in a city that was notorious for its unofficial apartheid, police harassment, identity cards for Aboriginals, curfews and bureaucratic obstruction. The club attracted interest from Black musicians both in Australia and overseas. Nat ‘King’ Cole, Harold Blair and the Harlem Globetrotters being among the international celebrities. As well as providing a place where the Aboriginal community could safely gather, the club was also known for its political activities. It issued a newspaper and later became an effective political organisation, speaking out on issues of the day which were affecting Aboriginal people. The exceptional achievement of the Coolbaroo League in finding an affirmative response to white oppression can be seen today as an important step forward in the development of Aboriginal self determination. The film is a powerful record of this achievement.
